The Meaning of the Perfection of Morality [SÅ«tra]: Because sin and non-sin cannot be obtained, one should perfect the perfection of morality.
[Treatise]: ÅšÄ«la means having a good nature in the Qin language. Liking to practice good ways and not being self-indulgent is called morality.
Either practicing good through receiving precepts or practicing good without receiving precepts is called morality.
Morality, in brief, is the eight kinds of bodily and verbal discipline:

Not harming, not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, not lying, not engaging in divisive speech, not engaging in harsh speech, not engaging in frivolous speech, not drinking alcohol, and maintaining a pure livelihood. These are called the characteristics of morality.
If one does not protect and abandons it, it is called breaking the precepts.
Those who violate this precept will fall into the three evil destinies.

If one upholds the precepts to a lesser degree, one will be reborn among humans; upholding them to a middling degree, one will be reborn among the six desire heavens; upholding them to a superior degree and practicing the four dhyanas and four formless concentrations, one will be reborn in the pure heavens of the form and formless realms.
There are three types of superior precept upholding:

Upholding the precepts to a lesser degree of purity results in becoming an arhat; upholding them to a middling degree of purity results in becoming a pratyekabuddha; upholding them to a superior degree of purity results in attaining Buddhahood.
Not being attached, not relying, not violating, not breaking, being praised and loved by the sages - this is called the superior pure precept upholding.

If one upholds the precepts out of compassion for sentient beings, in order to liberate sentient beings, and also because one understands the true nature of the precepts, one's mind will not be attached.
Upholding the precepts in this way will lead others to the Buddha's path. This is called attaining the precepts that lead to the unsurpassed Buddha's path.
If a person seeks great goodness and benefit, they should uphold the precepts as if they were precious treasures, and protect them as they would their own life.
Why is this?
It is like the great earth, all things with form rely on the earth to exist;
Precepts are also like this, precepts are the abode of all good dharmas.
Furthermore, it is like wanting to walk without feet, wanting to fly without wings, wanting to cross without a boat, this is impossible;
If one wants to obtain good fruits without precepts, it is also like this.
If a person abandons these precepts, although living in the mountains practicing austerities, eating fruits and taking medicine, they are no different from birds and beasts.
Some people only drink water as their precept, some drink milk, some drink qi;
Some shave their heads, some grow their hair, some leave a little hair on the top of their head;
Some wear kÄá¹£Äya robes, some wear white clothes, some wear grass robes, some wear bark robes;
Some enter the water in winter, some scorch themselves with fire in summer;
If they jump off a high cliff, or bathe in the Ganges River;
If they bathe three times a day and make offerings to the fire twice;
Various sacrifices, various blessings, and practicing austerities.
Without this precept, it is empty and nothing is gained.
If a person, although living in a high hall, wearing fine clothes and eating fine food, is able to practice this precept, they will be reborn in a good place and attain the fruits of the path.
Whether noble or humble, young or old, those who can practice this pure precept will all gain great benefits.
If this precept is broken, whether noble or humble, young or old, none will be able to be reborn in a good place as they wish.
Furthermore, a person of broken precepts is like a cool pond with a poisonous snake, unsuitable for bathing;
Also like a tree with fine flowers and fruits, but many thorns.
If a person, although born in a noble family, with a well-proportioned body, and widely learned, does not enjoy upholding the precepts and has no compassionate heart, it is also like this.
As a verse says:
Being noble but lacking wisdom leads to decline, being wise but arrogant also leads to decline,
Those who uphold precepts but violate them, will decline in this life and the next.
Although a person may be poor and lowly, if they can uphold the precepts, they are superior to those who are wealthy and noble but violate the precepts.
Flower fragrance and wood fragrance cannot be smelled from afar;
The fragrance of upholding the precepts permeates the ten directions.

Those who uphold the precepts are endowed with peace and joy, their fame is heard far and wide, they are respected and loved by gods and humans, and they always experience various pleasures in this life.
If they wish for heavenly realms, human realms, wealth, nobility, and longevity, it is not difficult to attain them;
By upholding the precepts purely, all their wishes will be fulfilled.

Furthermore, when those who uphold the precepts see those who violate the precepts being punished, interrogated, and suffering various hardships, they know that they themselves will forever be free from such things and take joy in this.
If a person who observes precepts sees a good person receiving praise, fame, and happiness, he thinks to himself:
Just as he receives praise, I also have a share.
When a person who observes precepts ends his life, the wind of the knife severs the body and cuts off the sinews and veins. Knowing that his precepts are pure, his mind is fearless.
As a verse says:
In the midst of great evil illness, precepts are the good medicine;
In the midst of great fear, precepts are the protection;
In the darkness of death, precepts are the bright lamp;
In the evil paths, precepts are the bridge;
In the waters of the sea of death, precepts are the great ship.

Furthermore, a person who observes precepts always receives respect and support from people in this world, his mind is happy and without regret, he lacks nothing in clothing and food, and after death he is reborn in the heavens and later attains Buddhahood.
For a person who observes precepts, nothing is unattainable;
For a person who breaks the precepts, everything is lost.
It is like a person who always makes offerings to the gods. That person, being poor, makes offerings with a sincere mind for twelve years, seeking wealth and nobility.
The gods take pity on this person and manifest their bodies to him, asking:
What do you seek?
He replies:
I seek wealth and nobility, wishing for all that my mind desires to be attained!
The gods give him a vessel called the virtuous vase and tell him:
The things you need will come out of this vase.
Having obtained it, he gets everything he wants, and there is nothing he cannot obtain.
Having obtained what he wishes for, he builds a fine house, with elephants, horses, carriages, and the seven treasures complete, providing for guests, with everything they need.
The guests ask him:
You were poor before, but now you have become so rich. What is the reason for this?
He replies:
I obtained a heavenly vase. The vase can produce these various things, so I am rich like this.
The guest said:
Take out the vase and show it, along with the things it produces!
He then took out the vase, and various things were drawn out from the vase.
The man, out of arrogance, stood on the vase and danced. The vase then broke, and all the various things also disappeared at once.
It is the same for a person who upholds the precepts. Various wonderful pleasures are obtained without fail;
If a person breaks the precepts, is arrogant, and indulges themselves, it is also like that person breaking the vase and losing the things.
Furthermore, for a person who upholds the precepts, the fragrance of their good reputation spreads throughout the present world, the next world, the heavens, and among humans.
Furthermore, for a person who upholds the precepts, people enjoy giving to them. They do not begrudge their wealth and possessions. Without cultivating worldly benefits, they have nothing lacking;
They are reborn in the heavens and in front of the Buddhas of the ten directions. Entering the path of the Three Vehicles, they attain liberation.
Only various wrong views and precepts will not bring any gain in the end.
Moreover, even if a person does not leave the household life, but is able to practice the precepts, they can still be reborn in the heavens.
If a person upholds the precepts purely, practices meditation and wisdom, and wishes to be liberated from the suffering of old age, sickness, and death, this wish will surely be fulfilled.
A person who upholds the precepts, even without weapons, will not be harmed by evil;
The wealth of upholding the precepts cannot be stolen by anyone;
The relatives of upholding the precepts will not leave even in death;
The adornment of upholding the precepts surpasses the seven treasures.
For this reason, one should protect the precepts as one would protect one's body and life, as one would cherish precious possessions.
A person who breaks the precepts will suffer in myriad ways, like the poor man who broke the jar and lost his belongings. For this reason, one should uphold pure precepts.
Moreover, a person who upholds the precepts, observing the offenses of those who break the precepts, should encourage themselves and uphold the precepts with a single mind.
What are the offenses of those who violate the precepts?
Those who violate the precepts are not respected by people, their homes are like graveyards, and people do not go near them.
Those who violate the precepts lose all their merits, like a withered tree that people do not enjoy.
Those who violate the precepts are like frost-bitten lotus flowers, and people do not like to see them.
Those who violate the precepts have evil and fearful minds, like rÄká¹£asas.
Those who violate the precepts are not turned to for refuge, like a thirsty person does not go to a dried-up well.
Those who violate the precepts always have doubts and regrets in their minds, like a person who has committed an offense always fears punishment.
Those who violate the precepts are like a field struck by hail, and cannot be relied upon.
Those who violate the precepts are like bitter gourds, although their appearance resembles sweet seeds but cannot be eaten.
Those who violate the precepts are like a gathering of thieves, and cannot be relied upon.
Those who violate the precepts are like a great illness, and people do not want to get close to them.
One who breaks the precepts cannot escape suffering, just as a bad path is difficult to pass through.
One who breaks the precepts cannot be associated with, just as a bad thief is difficult to befriend.
One who breaks the precepts is like a great pit, which practitioners avoid.
One who breaks the precepts is difficult to live with, like a poisonous snake.ğŸ”½One who breaks the precepts cannot be approached, like a great fire.
One who breaks the precepts is like a broken boat, which cannot be used to cross over.

One who breaks the precepts is like vomit, which cannot be eaten again.ğŸ”½One who breaks the precepts in a good assembly is like a bad horse in a herd of good horses.ğŸ”½One who breaks the precepts is different from a good person, like a donkey in a herd of cows.
One who breaks the precepts in an assembly of diligent practitioners is like a weakling among strong people.
One who breaks the precepts, though resembling a bhiká¹£u, is like a corpse among sleeping people.
A person of broken precepts is like a fake jewel among real jewels.
A person of broken precepts is like an iron-wood tree in a sandalwood forest.
A person of broken precepts, though outwardly resembling a good person, has no good Dharma within;
Though he shaves his head, dyes his robes, and holds the counting stick in order, he is called a bhiká¹£u but is truly not a bhiká¹£u.
If a person of broken precepts wears the Dharma robes, it is like wrapping oneself in hot copper sheets;
If he holds a begging bowl, it is like holding a vessel filled with molten copper;ğŸ”½If he eats what is offered, it is like swallowing burning iron pellets and drinking hot molten copper;
If he receives offerings and support from others, it is like being guarded by the hell wardens;
If he enters the monastery, it is like entering a great hell;
If he sits on the bed or bench of the saá¹ƒgha, it is like sitting on a bed of hot iron.
Furthermore, a person of broken precepts is always fearful, like a seriously ill person who constantly fears death approaching.
It is also like a person who has committed the five heinous crimes, always thinking in their mind, I am a thief of the Buddha, hiding and avoiding others;
Like a thief fearing people, as the years, months, and days pass, they are always uneasy.
A person who has broken the precepts, although they may obtain offerings and pleasures, this pleasure is impure;
It is like a foolish person who makes offerings and adorns a corpse. The wise, upon hearing of it, dislike it and do not wish to see it.
There are various immeasurable offenses of breaking the precepts like this, which cannot be fully described. Practitioners should uphold the precepts with a single mind.
The meaning of the characteristics of precepts, explained in the first chapter of the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra, part 22, section 1. Question:
Having understood the various merits and rewards like this, what is called the characteristics of precepts?
Answer:

Stopping evil and not doing it again, whether it arises in the mind, is spoken with the mouth, or is received from others, ceasing the evil of body and speech, this is the characteristics of precepts.
What is called evil?
If it is truly a sentient being, knowing it is a sentient being, with the intention to kill, one deprives it of life, and there is bodily karma with form, this is called the offense of killing.
The rest, such as binding and beating, are methods that assist in killing.
Furthermore, one obtains the offense of killing by killing others, not by killing oneself.
Knowing in the mind that it is a sentient being and killing it is called the offense of killing, unlike killing someone at night, mistaking them for a stump.
Therefore, one obtains the offense of killing by intentionally killing, not unintentionally.
One obtains the offense of killing by killing with a joyful mind, not by being insane.
The offense of killing is when the life faculty is cut off, not when a wound is inflicted.
The offense of killing is bodily karma, not just verbal instruction.
The offense of killing is verbal instruction, not just mental arising.
These are called the offenses of killing;
Not committing these offenses is called morality.
If a person receives the precepts, the mind arises and the mouth speaks:
From today onward, I will no longer kill living beings!
If one does not move the body, does not speak, but alone gives rise to a vow in the mind,
From today onwards, I will no longer kill living beings!
This is called the precept against killing.
Some people say:
This precept against killing is either wholesome or indeterminate.
Question:
As it is said in the Abhidharma, All precepts and disciplines are wholesome, why is it said to be indeterminate now?
Answer:
As it is said in KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra's Abhidharma that all are wholesome, as in other Abhidharmas it is said that the precept against killing is either wholesome or indeterminate.
Why is this?
If the precept against killing is always wholesome, a person who upholds this precept should be like one who has attained the Way, and should never fall into evil realms.
For this reason, it should sometimes be indeterminate;
because the indeterminate has no karmic retribution, one is not reborn in the heavens or among humans.
Question:
It is not because the precepts are indeterminate that one falls into hell; rather, one falls into hell because of the arising of further evil thoughts.
Answer:
By not killing, one attains immeasurable wholesome dharmas, and merit is constantly produced day and night, whether one is active or not;
If one commits a small offense, it is limited and has a measure.
Why is it limited and not unlimited?
For this reason, we know that within the precept of not killing, there may be indeterminate [actions].
Furthermore, there are people who do not receive precepts from a teacher, but simply give rise to a vow in their minds:
From today onwards, I will no longer kill living beings!
Such non-killing may sometimes be indeterminate.
Question:
To which realm is this precept of not killing connected?
Answer:
As it is said in KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra's Abhidharma:
All precepts and disciplines are connected to the desire realm.
In other Abhidharmas, it is said:
They may be connected to the desire realm or not connected.
If we speak in reality, there should be three kinds:
Either belonging to the desire realm, belonging to the form realm, or pure.
Although the method of killing is in the desire realm, the precept against killing should follow killing and be in the desire realm;
But the precept against killing in the form realm and the precept against killing that is pure are true precepts against killing because they are far removed from killing.
Furthermore, there are people who do not take precepts but who, since birth, do not like to kill, either good or indeterminate. This is called indeterminate.
This method of not killing is neither mind nor mental factors, nor is it associated with mind;
It may arise together with the mind or not arise together with the mind.
In the Abhidharma of KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra, it is said:
Not killing is either bodily or verbal action, either form or non-form, sometimes following the mind or not following the mind (annotation:
Following the mind:
The precepts that accompany concentration;
Not following the mind:
The five precepts are not the result of karma from previous lives.
There are two kinds of cultivation that should be cultivated, and two kinds of realization that should be realized.
The sutra says: Realization through the body and realization through wisdom.
What is to be eliminated through contemplation is obtained last in the desire realm;
What is to be eliminated through insight and what is to be eliminated through time are obtained by both ordinary people and sages.
This is a form dharma, which may be visible or invisible, may be resistant or non-resistant, has retribution, has results, is defiled, is conditioned, and has a higher level.
Because it is not ultimate, it has a higher level, and is not a corresponding cause.
Such distinctions are called the precept of not killing.
The question is asked:
Among the eightfold noble path, the precept also does not kill. Why is it said that the precept of not killing has retribution and is defiled?
The answer is:
Here, it only explains the Dharma of receiving precepts and observances, not the Dharma of precepts and observances without outflows.
Furthermore, in other Abhidharma texts, it is said:
The principle of not killing does not always follow the mind, it is not bodily or verbal action, it does not follow the mind's actions;
it may have retribution, or it may not;
it is not a mind-associated dharma, it may be contaminated, or it may be uncontaminated.
This is a different principle, the rest are the same.
There are also those who say:
The Buddhas and sages do not engage in conceptual proliferation regarding dharmas. The Dunhuang annotation says:
Various different explanations are called 'conceptual proliferation.' Sentient beings in the present all cherish their own lives, therefore the Buddha says not to deprive others of life;
depriving others of life, one will experience various sufferings in life after life.
Whether sentient beings exist or not will be discussed later.
Question:
People can use their strength to defeat others, conquer countries, and kill enemies, or hunt for their skin and meat, which benefits many.
If one is made to refrain from killing, what benefits does one gain?
Answer:
One gains fearlessness and peaceful bliss.
Because I do not harm others, others do not harm me. For this reason, there is no fear or terror.
Even if a person who likes killing attains the position of the supreme king, they will still not be at ease;
it is like a person who observes the precepts, traveling alone without any fear or difficulty.
Furthermore, those who have life will not enjoy seeing a person who likes killing;
if one does not like killing, all beings will happily rely on them.
Furthermore, when a person who observes the precepts is about to die, their mind is at ease, without doubt or regret;
whether reborn in the heavens or among humans, they will always attain a long life;
this is the cause and condition for attaining the Way, up to attaining Buddhahood and abiding with immeasurable life.
Furthermore, a person who kills will experience various physical and mental sufferings in this world and the next;
a person who does not kill is free from these many difficulties, this is a great benefit.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates:
I myself cherish my life and love my body, and others are the same. What is the difference between them and me?
For this reason, one should not kill.
Furthermore, if a person kills, they are scolded by good people and envied by enemies.
Because they owe the lives of others, they are always in fear and are hated by them.
When they die, they regret it and will fall into hell or the realm of animals.
If they are reborn as humans, they will always have a short life.
Furthermore, even if there is no crime in the afterlife, and they are not scolded by good people or envied by enemies, one should still not intentionally deprive others of their lives.
Why is this?
It is not something that a person with good characteristics should do, let alone having crimes in both worlds and evil consequences!
Furthermore, killing is the heaviest of crimes.
Why is this?
When a person is in a life-threatening emergency, they do not spare precious treasures, but only prioritize saving their life.

It is like a merchant who enters the ocean to collect treasures. As he is about to emerge from the great ocean, his ship suddenly breaks up and all his precious treasures are lost. He rejoices and raises his hands, saying:
How close I came to losing my great treasures!
The people wonder and say:
You have lost your wealth and escaped naked. Why do you rejoice and say you almost lost your great treasures?
He replies:
Among all treasures, human life is the most important.
For the sake of life, people seek wealth, not for the sake of wealth do they seek life.
For this reason, the Buddha says that among the ten unwholesome deeds, the sin of killing comes first;
It is also the first among the five precepts.
If a person cultivates various merits and virtues but does not have the precept of not killing, it will be of no benefit.
Why is this?
Even if born in a wealthy and noble place with power and strength, without a lifespan, who will enjoy this happiness?
For this reason, one knows that among the other sins, the sin of killing is the most serious;
Among all merits, not killing is the foremost.
In the world, cherishing life is the foremost.
How do we know this?
All worldly people are willing to undergo punishments, mutilations, and torture to protect their lives.
Furthermore, if a person receives the precepts and gives rise to the thought:
From today onwards, I will not kill any living being.
This is already giving away what is cherished to innumerable beings, and the merit obtained is also immeasurable.
As the Buddha said:
There are five great acts of giving. What are the five?
First, not killing living beings, this is the greatest act of giving;
not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, not speaking falsely, and not drinking alcohol are also like this.
Furthermore, practicing the samadhi of loving-kindness has immeasurable blessings. Water and fire cannot harm it, swords and weapons cannot injure it, and all evil poisons cannot affect it;
Because of the five great acts of giving, one obtains such rewards.
Furthermore, among the honored ones of the three times and ten directions, the Buddha is the foremost.
As the Buddha said to the upÄsaka Nandika:
There are ten offenses for killing living beings. What are the ten?
First, one always harbors poison, which continues from lifetime to lifetime;
Second, sentient beings detest and dislike seeing [the killer];
Third, one always harbors evil thoughts and contemplates evil matters;
Fourth, sentient beings fear [the killer] as if seeing a snake or tiger;
Fifth, when sleeping, the mind is frightened, and upon waking, one is also uneasy;
Sixth, one always has evil dreams;
Seventh, at the time of death, one dies in a state of madness and terror;
Eighth, one plants the causes and conditions for a short life;
Ninth, when the body perishes and life ends, one falls into the hells;
Tenth, if one is reborn as a human, one will always have a short life.
Furthermore, the practitioner thinks:
All living beings, down to insects, all cherish their own bodies;
How can one kill sentient beings for the sake of one's own body and clothing and food?
Furthermore, the practitioner should study the Dharma of great beings. Among all great beings, the Buddha is the greatest.
Why is this?

He has accomplished all wisdom, is endowed with the ten powers, is able to deliver sentient beings, always practices compassion, upholds the precept against killing, and has attained Buddhahood himself. He also teaches his disciples to practice this compassion.
Because the practitioner wishes to study the conduct of great beings, he should also refrain from killing.
Question:
If someone does not harm me, the thought of killing can be put to rest;
but if they harm me, forcibly take from me, and oppress me, what should I do then?
Answer:
One should measure the severity of the situation.
If someone kills me, I should first contemplate:
Is the benefit of upholding the precepts heavy?
Or is preserving my body heavy?
Is losing the precepts a loss?
Is losing my life a loss?
Having contemplated in this way, he knew that upholding the precepts was important and that preserving one's body was secondary.
If one merely escapes with one's life, what does one gain?
This body is called the den of old age, sickness, and death, and it will surely decay and fail.
If one loses one's life for the sake of upholding the precepts, the benefit is very great.
He contemplated further:
In the past and present, I have lost my body countless times in various lifetimes, either as a vicious thief or the body of a beast, only for the sake of wealth and other unwholesome matters;

Now, I have attained the ability to uphold pure precepts, and I do not begrudge this body. Giving up my life to uphold the precepts is a hundred thousand times better than keeping the precepts while preserving my body, and it is beyond comparison.
With such a determined mind, I should give up my body to protect the pure precepts.
Like a person who has entered the stream and is born into a butcher's family;
As he approaches adulthood, he should practice his family's occupation, but he is unwilling to kill living beings.
His parents gave him a knife and a sheep, locked him in a room, and said to him:
If you do not kill the sheep, we will not let you out, see the sun and moon, or live and eat.
The child thought to himself:
If I kill this sheep, I will end up doing this kind of work. How can I commit such a great sin for the sake of my body?
He then killed himself with the knife.
When his parents opened the door, they saw the sheep standing in one corner, and the child had already died.
When he killed himself, he was immediately reborn in the heavens.
If it is like this, this is not cherishing one's life and fully protecting pure precepts.
Such meanings are called the precept against killing.

As for taking what is not given, knowing that it belongs to another, giving rise to the thought of stealing, taking the object and moving it away from its original place, thinking The object belongs to me, this is called stealing.
If one does not do this, it is called not stealing.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Other skillful means and calculations, up to holding it in the hand but not yet leaving the ground, are called methods of assisting in theft.
There are two kinds of property:
Some belong to others, some do not belong to others.
Taking what belongs to others is a crime of theft.
What belongs to others is also of two kinds:
One is in the village, the other is on open ground.
Stealing the property in these two places is a crime of theft.
If the property is on open ground, one should examine whose country it is near.
This property should belong to someone and should not be taken.
As explained in the Vinaya, various kinds of non-stealing are called the characteristics of non-stealing.
Question:
What are the benefits of not stealing?
Answer:
Human life is of two kinds:
One is internal, the other is external.
If one takes away property, it is taking away external life.
Why is it so?
Life depends on food, clothing, and other things to survive. If one robs or steals, this is called stealing external life.
As a verse says:
All sentient beings, with clothing and food to sustain themselves;
If one robs or steals, this is called stealing life.
For this reason, an intelligent person should not rob or steal.
Furthermore, one should contemplate:
Even if one obtains things through robbery and theft to provide for oneself, although the body may be satisfied, one will still die;
After death, one enters hell. Although family and relatives may enjoy pleasures together, one alone will suffer the consequences and they will not be able to save one.
Having attained this contemplation, one should not steal.
Furthermore, stealing has two types:
First, stealing; second, robbery.
These two are collectively called stealing.
Among stealing, theft is the most serious.
Why is it so?
All people use wealth to sustain themselves, but some may pierce and steal, which is the most impure.
Why is this?
Because the powerless conquer the powerful, fearing death and stealing.
Among robberies, stealing is the heaviest crime, as a verse says:
Starving, the body emaciated, suffering great pain and hardship;
Other's possessions cannot be touched, like a great mass of fire.
If one steals other's possessions, the owner weeps and laments;
Even if the heavenly kings and others, it is still considered painful.
Although the crime of killing is heavy, the killer is a thief to the killed, and the thief is a thief to all who possess things.
If one violates other precepts, in other countries it may not be considered a crime;
But if one steals, in all countries the crime will be punished.
Question:
As for the person who steals, in this world there are people who praise their strength, so why not engage in this stealing?
Answer:
Stealing what is not given is an unwholesome characteristic;
within stealing, although there are differences, they are all unwholesome.
It is like delicious food mixed with poison and bad food mixed with poison - although the delicious and bad are different, the mixed poison is no different.
It is also like walking on fire in the light and darkness - although the day and night are different, the burning of the feet is the same.

The foolish people of this world do not recognize the fruits and retributions of sin and blessings in the two worlds, have no compassionate heart, see people able to encroach on each other with force, forcefully take others' wealth, and praise them for being strong.
The Buddhas and sages have compassion for all, clearly understand the calamities and misfortunes of the three worlds that do not decay, and do not praise them.
For this reason, know that the sin of stealing is all unwholesome, and is not done by those who practice goodness.
As the Buddha said:
Stealing has ten offenses. What are the ten?
First, the owner is always angry;
Second, heavy suspicion. The annotation says:
Heavy offenses are suspected;
Third, not considering at the wrong time;
Fourth, befriending evil people and staying away from the virtuous;
Fifth, destroying good relations;
Sixth, incurring offenses against the government;
Seventh, property being confiscated;
Eighth, planting the causes and conditions for poverty;
Ninth, upon death, entering hell;
Tenth, if reborn as a human, struggling to seek wealth, which is shared by the five:
Either the king, thieves, fire, water, or unloved children use it, and even if buried, it is lost.
As for sexual misconduct, if a woman is protected by her parents, brothers, sisters, husband, sons, worldly laws, or royal laws, to violate her is called sexual misconduct.
If there are those who, although not guarded, are guarded by the Dharma;
How is it guarded by the Dharma?
All ordained women and laywomen who receive the precepts for one day are called guarded by the Dharma.
If by force, by wealth, or by deception;
If one has one's own wife who has received the precepts, is pregnant, is breastfeeding, or is not the proper way, such an offense is called sexual misconduct.
Such various acts, up to giving a garland of flowers to a prostitute as a promise, such an offense is called sexual misconduct.
Not committing such various acts is called not engaging in sexual misconduct.
Question:
If one is guarded by a person but the person is angry, and one is guarded by the Dharma but the Dharma is broken, it should be called sexual misconduct;
If one has one's own wife, how can it be considered wrong?
Answer:
Since one is allowed to receive the precepts for one day, one falls into the Dharma;
Although one may be one's own wife, one is not free now;
After the time of receiving the precepts, one is not guarded by the Dharma.
Pregnant women, because of the heaviness of their bodies, dislike their usual practices, and it also harms the fetus.
When a child is breastfed, if one has sex with the mother, the milk will dry up;
And because the mind is attached to sexual desire, one no longer protects the child.
Places other than the proper way are not the female organ. The woman's mind is not happy. Forcibly using improper means is called sexual misconduct.
Not engaging in this is called not engaging in sexual misconduct.
Question:
If the husband does not know, see, or is not bothered by it, what crime does the other person have?
Answer:
Because it is wrong;
Since it is called wrong, it is not right, and therefore there is a crime.
Furthermore, this has various faults. The feelings of a married couple are different bodies but the same essence. Taking away what the other loves, breaking their original mind, is called theft.
There are also grave crimes, bad reputation, and being hated by people;
There is little pleasure and much fear, or fear of capital punishment, and also fear of being known by one's husband or others;
One often harbors lies, which are condemned by the sages. Among offenses, it is the offense of offenses. The annotation in the Chinese version states:
The offense of sexual misconduct, because sexual misconduct breaks the precepts, is called the offense of offenses.
Furthermore, a person who engages in sexual misconduct should contemplate:

My wife and others' wives are the same in being women. In terms of bones, flesh, emotions, and temperament, there is no difference between them. Then why do I give rise to deluded thoughts and follow deviant intentions?
A person who engages in sexual misconduct loses the pleasures of this world and the next. The benefits of a good reputation, mental and physical peace and happiness are obtained in this world;
The benefits of being reborn in the heavens, attaining the Way, and attaining nirvana are obtained in the next world.
Furthermore, by reversing one's own situation, one restrains one's mind:
If they violate my wife, I will become angry;
If I violate them, what is the difference?
Therefore, one should not do what one would not want done to oneself.
Furthermore, as the Buddha said:
Those who engage in sexual misconduct will later fall into the sword-tree hell, where they will experience all kinds of suffering;
Upon leaving there, they will become human, but their family life will be discordant, and they will always encounter licentious wives and crooked thieves.
Sexual misconduct is a calamity, like a poisonous snake or a great fire. If one does not quickly avoid it, disaster will strike!
As the Buddha said:
There are ten offenses in sexual misconduct:
First, one is always sought after by the husbands of those one has had affairs with, who wish to harm one;
Second, husband and wife are not harmonious and always quarrel;
Third, unwholesome dharmas increase day by day, while wholesome dharmas decrease day by day;
Fourth, one does not protect one's body, and one's children and wife become orphans;
Fifth, one's wealth and property are consumed day by day;
Sixth, one has many evil things and is always suspected by others;
Seventh, they are not loved and delighted in by relatives and acquaintances;
Eighth, they create the causes and conditions for enmity;
Ninth, when their body perishes and their life ends, they die and enter hell;
Tenth, if they are born as women, they will have many husbands;
If they are born as men, their wives will be unchaste.
Not engaging in these various causes and conditions is called not engaging in sexual misconduct.
Lying means with an impure mind, wishing to deceive others, concealing the truth, speaking differently, and giving rise to verbal karma. This is called lying.
The offense of lying arises from the spoken words being understood;
If they are not understood, even if one speaks untruthfully, there is no offense of lying.
This lying means saying I do not know when one knows, and saying I know when one does not know;
Saying I do not see when one sees, and saying I see when one does not see;
Saying I do not hear when one hears, and saying I hear when one does not hear - this is called lying.
Not engaging in this is called not lying.
Question:
What are the offenses of false speech?
Answer:
One who speaks falsely first deceives oneself and then deceives others;
taking the real as false, taking the false as real, with upside-down falsity and truth, one does not accept wholesome dharmas.
It is like covering a bottle, water cannot enter.
One who speaks falsely has no sense of shame in the mind, blocking the heavenly path and the gate to nirvana.
Contemplating and knowing this offense, therefore one does not commit it.

Furthermore, contemplating and knowing that the benefits of true speech are very vast, the benefits of true speech come from oneself and are very easy to obtain, this is the power of all renunciant people.
Such merits are shared by lay and renunciant people, the characteristics of good people.
Furthermore, one who speaks truthfully has an upright mind;
with an upright mind, it is easy to escape suffering.
It is like pulling wood through a dense forest, the straight one is easy to pull out.
Question:
If lying has such grave consequences, why do people lie?
Answer:
Some people are foolish and ignorant, and when they encounter difficult and perilous situations, they lie to seek release;
They do not know that revealing the matter will result in offenses in this world, nor do they know that there will be grave consequences in the next world.
Some people, although they know the consequences of lying, still lie due to excessive greed, hatred, and delusion.
Some people, although not greedy or hateful, falsely testify to someone's guilt, thinking it is true, and die and fall into hell.
Like Devadatta's disciple KokÄlika, who always sought faults in ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana.
At that time, after the two had completed their summer retreat, they traveled to various countries. Encountering heavy rain, they stayed in a potter's house where pottery was stored.
In this house, a woman was already staying in the dark. The two did not know.
That night, this woman dreamed of losing her virginity. In the morning, she went to the water to wash.
At that time, KokÄlika happened to be walking by and saw her.
KokÄlika was able to discern the physical characteristics of people who had engaged in sexual intercourse, but he did not know whether it was in a dream or not.
At that time, KokÄlika looked back and said to his disciple:
This woman had sexual relations with someone last night.
He then asked the woman:
Where did you sleep?
She replied:
I stayed overnight in the potter's house.
He asked again:
With whom?
She answered:
With two bhiká¹£us.
At that time, the two people came out of the house. KokÄlika saw them and, judging by their physical characteristics, concluded that the two must have engaged in impure acts.
Previously harboring jealousy, upon seeing this, he went to the towns and villages to spread the bad news;
next, he went to Jetavana and proclaimed this evil rumor.
In the meantime, Brahma Heaven King came wanting to see the Buddha.
The Buddha entered the quiet room and was in silent samadhi;
The assembly of bhiká¹£us were also each in their rooms in samadhi, all unawakened.
He then thought to himself:
I came on purpose to see the Buddha, but the Buddha is in samadhi, so I will just return.
He then thought again:
It will not be long before the Buddha emerges from his concentration, so I will stay here for a while.
He went to the front of KÄÅ›yapa's room, knocked on the door, and said:ğŸ”½KÄÅ›yapa!
KÄÅ›yapa!
ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana's minds are pure and pliable, do not slander them and suffer for a long time!
KÄÅ›yapa asked:
Who are you?
He replied:
I am the king of the Brahma Heaven.
He asked:
The Buddha said you have attained the path of the non-returner, why have you come?
BrahmÄ thought and spoke this verse:
Desiring to measure immeasurable dharmas, one should not grasp them with characteristics;
Desiring to measure immeasurable dharmas, this is a wild person's submergence!
Having spoken this verse, he went to where the Buddha was and fully explained the matter.
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
You have spoken this verse well!
At that time, the World-Honored One again spoke this verse:
Desiring to measure immeasurable dharmas, one should not grasp them with characteristics;
Desiring to measure immeasurable dharmas, this is a wild person's submergence!
BrahmÄ King listened to the Buddha's explanation, suddenly disappeared, and immediately returned to the heavens.
At that time, KokÄlika went to where the Buddha was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, and stood to one side.
The Buddha told KokÄlika:
ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana's minds are pure and pliable. Do not slander them and suffer for a long time!
KokÄlika said to the Buddha:
I dare not disbelieve the Buddha's words, but I have seen with my own eyes that these two people definitely engaged in impure conduct.
The Buddha reprimanded him like this three times, but KokÄlika did not accept it three times, and then he got up and left.

When he returned to his room, boils appeared all over his body, starting as small as mustard seeds, gradually growing as large as beans, jujubes, and oranges, and then as big as gourds, suddenly bursting open, like being burned by a great fire. He wailed and howled, and that night he died and entered the Great Lotus Flower Hell.
A Brahma god came to the Buddha in the night and said:
KokÄlika has already died.
Another Brahma god said:
He has fallen into the Great Lotus Flower Hell.
After the night passed, the Buddha ordered the Sangha to gather and told them:
Do you want to know the length of KokÄlika's life in hell?
The monks said:
We wish to hear it with joy!
The Buddha said:
There are sixty bushels of sesame seeds. If a person were to take one sesame seed every hundred years, this would continue until they are all gone. The lifespan in the AvÄ«ci Hell has not yet ended.

The lifespan in twenty AvÄ«ci Hells is the lifespan in one Nirarbuda Hell;ğŸ”½The lifespan in twenty Nirarbuda Hells is the lifespan in one Aá¹­aá¹­a Hell;ğŸ”½The lifespan in twenty Aá¹­aá¹­a Hells is the lifespan in one Ahaha Hell;

The lifespan in twenty Ahaha Hells is the lifespan in one Huhuva Hell;ğŸ”½The lifespan in twenty Huhuva Hells is the lifespan in one Utpala Hell;ğŸ”½The lifespan in twenty Utpala Hells is the lifespan in one Padma Hell;
The lifespan in twenty Padma Hells is the lifespan in one MahÄpadma Hell.
KÄtyÄyananandin fell into the AvÄ«ci Hell, where his tongue was pulled out and nailed with a hundred nails, and five hundred plows were used on it.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke this verse:
When a person is born, an axe is in their mouth;
The reason for cutting their body is due to their evil speech.
They should rebuke but praise, they should praise but rebuke;
The mouth accumulates all evils, and they will never see happiness!
If the mind and mouth create evil karma, one will fall into the Niraya Hell;
For a full hundred thousand years, one will experience various poisonous sufferings.
If born in the AvÄ«ci Hell, for a full thirty-six;
There are also five separate lives, all experiencing various poisonous sufferings.
The mind relies on wrong views, destroying the words of the sages;
Like bamboo producing fruit, it destroys its own form.
Doubts and denials arise in such minds, and they also become false speech.
Those who tell lies do not believe even the Buddha's words, and they receive such punishments.
For this reason, one should not tell lies.
Furthermore, the Buddha's disciple RÄhula, being young and inexperienced, did not know how to be careful with his words.
When people came to ask him,
Is the World-Honored One here?
He would jokingly say,
He is not here.
If the Buddha was not there, people would ask RÄhula,
Is the World-Honored One here?
He would jokingly say,
The Buddha is here.
Someone told the Buddha,
and the Buddha said to RÄhula,
Take the washbasin and water, and wash my feet.
After washing his feet, the Buddha said to RÄhula,
Cover this washbasin.
As instructed, he immediately covered it.
The Buddha said,
Pour water into it.
After pouring, he asked,
Does the water enter?
He replied:
It does not enter!
The Buddha told Rahula:
A person without shame or conscience, whose mind is covered by lies, the Dharma does not enter them, it is also like this!
As the Buddha said:
There are ten offenses for telling lies. What are the ten?
First, one's breath smells bad;
Second, good spirits stay away and non-humans take advantage;
Third, even if one speaks the truth, others do not believe it;
Fourth, one is always excluded from discussions among the wise;
Fifth, one is always slandered and ugly rumors spread all over the world;
Sixth, people do not respect one, and even if one gives orders, others do not follow them;
Seventh, one always has much worry and sorrow;
Eighth, one creates the causes and conditions for slanderous karma;
Ninth, when one's body perishes and life ends, one will fall into hell;
Tenth, if one is reborn as a human, one will always be slandered.
Not doing these various things is called not lying, and is called good conduct of the mouth.
As for not drinking alcohol, there are three kinds of alcohol:
First, grain alcohol, second, fruit alcohol, and third, medicinal herb alcohol.
Fruit alcohol refers to alcohol made from jujube, jujube, and other such fruits.
Medicinal herb alcohol refers to various medicinal herbs mixed with rice koji and sugarcane juice that can turn into alcohol.
Alcohol made from the milk of cloven-hoofed animals and all milk that has been heated can be used to make alcohol.
In short, whether dry or wet, clear or turbid, if it can cause the mind to become agitated and reckless, it is called alcohol.
One should not drink any of it, and this is called not drinking alcohol.
Question:
Alcohol can cure cold, benefit the body, and make the mind joyful. Why not drink it?
Answer:
The benefits to the body are very few, while the harm is very great, therefore one should not drink.
It is like a delicious drink mixed with poison. What kind of poison is it?
As the Buddha told the upÄsaka Nandika:
Wine has thirty-five faults.
What are the thirty-five?
First, in this life, wealth is exhausted. Why is it so?
Because when people drink wine and become intoxicated, their minds have no restraint and their spending is unrestrained;
Second, it is the door to various illnesses;
Third, it is the root of quarrels;
Fourth, it leads to nudity and shamelessness;
Fifth, it brings about an ugly reputation and bad name, and one is not respected by others;
Sixth, it obscures wisdom;
Seventh, one fails to obtain the things one should obtain, and the things one has obtained are lost;
Eighth, all secret matters are told to others;
Ninth, various undertakings are abandoned and not accomplished;
Tenth, intoxication is the root of sorrow. Why is it so?
Because there are many mistakes in intoxication, one feels ashamed and sorrowful upon sobering up;
Eleventh, one's physical strength gradually decreases;
Twelfth, one's complexion deteriorates;
Thirteenth, one does not know how to respect one's father;
Fourteenth, one does not know how to respect one's mother;
Fifteenth, one does not respect Å›ramaá¹‡as;
Sixteenth, one does not respect brÄhmans;
Seventeenth, one does not respect one's uncles and elders. Why is it so?
Because one is confused and disoriented in intoxication and cannot distinguish anything;
Eighteenth, one does not respect the Buddha;
Nineteenth, one does not respect the Dharma;
Twentieth, one does not respect the Saá¹ƒgha;
Twenty-first, one associates with evil people;
Twenty-second, one distances oneself from the virtuous;
Twenty-third, one becomes a person who violates the precepts;
Twenty-fourth, one has no sense of shame or remorse;
Twenty-fifth, one does not guard the six senses;
Twenty-sixth, indulging in sensual desires;
Twenty-seventh, being disliked by others and unpleasant to see;
Twenty-eighth, being abandoned by valuable relatives and friends;
Twenty-ninth, practicing unwholesome dharmas;
Thirtieth, abandoning wholesome dharmas;
Thirty-first, not trusted by wise and intelligent people, why is this?
Because of the heedlessness of alcohol;
Thirty-second, being far from nirvana;
Thirty-third, planting the causes and conditions for madness;
Thirty-fourth, at the end of one's life and body, falling into the evil destinies and hells;
Thirty-fifth, if one obtains a human birth, one will always be insane and foolish.
There are various faults like this, therefore one should not drink.
As a verse says:
Alcohol loses one's sense of propriety, one's complexion becomes turbid and ugly,
The mind of wisdom moves and becomes confused, and shame and conscience are then robbed.
Forgetting mindfulness increases the mind of anger, losing joy and destroying the clan;
Thus, although it is called drinking, it is actually drinking the poison of death.
One should not be angry when one should not be angry, one should not laugh when one should not laugh,
One should not cry when one should not cry, one should not beat when one should not beat,
One should not speak when one should not speak, one is no different from a madman;
Stealing away all wholesome merits, those who know shame do not drink.
Thus, not committing these four offenses is the good conduct of the body;
Not committing false speech is the good conduct of the mouth;
This is called the five precepts and conduct of an upÄsaka.
Question:
If the eight kinds of conduct and pure livelihood are called precepts,
Why does the upÄsaka not have the three kinds of conduct and pure livelihood among the precepts of the mouth?
Answer:
Laypeople live at home, enjoy worldly pleasures, and cultivate blessings and virtues. They cannot fully practice the precepts, so the Buddha has them observe the five precepts.
Moreover, among the four kinds of verbal actions, false speech is the most serious.
Moreover, false speech is done with a deliberate mind;
the others may be done deliberately or not deliberately.
Moreover, by simply speaking of false speech, the three matters are already included.
Moreover, among all wholesome dharmas, truth is the greatest;
if one speaks truthfully, all four kinds of right speech are already included.
Moreover, laypeople in the world have official duties and family work, so it is difficult to observe the precept against harsh speech.
False speech is done deliberately, and the matter is serious, so it should not be done.
These five precepts are received in five ways, and are called the five kinds of upÄsakas:

First, the upÄsaka who practices a portion; second, the upÄsaka who practices a small portion; third, the upÄsaka who practices a large portion; fourth, the upÄsaka who practices fully; fifth, the upÄsaka who abstains from sexual activity.
The one who practices a portion receives one precept out of the five precepts and is unable to uphold the four precepts;
The one who practices a small portion receives two precepts or three precepts;
The one who practices a large portion receives four precepts;
The one who practices fully upholds all five precepts;
The one who abstains from sexual activity, after receiving the five precepts, makes a vow in front of the teacher, saying:
I will no longer engage in sexual activity with my own wife.
This is called the five precepts.
As a Buddha verse says:
Not killing, not stealing, and not engaging in sexual misconduct,
Speaking truthfully, not drinking alcohol, with right livelihood and a pure mind.
If one is able to practice this, worries and fears in the two realms are eliminated,
The merit of precepts always accompanies the body, and one is always with devas and humans.
The six seasonal flowers in the world, their radiant colors blooming,
With these flowers of a year, a day in the heavens is complete.
Heavenly trees naturally produce flower garlands and necklaces,
Red petals like lamps illuminating, various colors intermingled.
Countless heavenly garments, their colors of various kinds,
Bright white reflecting the heavenly sun, light and dense without gaps;
Golden color shining on embroidered patterns, swirling like cloud vapors,
Such sublime garments all come from the heavenly trees.
Luminous pearls, heavenly earrings, and precious stones shining on hands and feet,
In accordance with the heart's beloved, also come from the heavenly trees.
Golden flowers with lapis lazuli stems, vajra for flower stamens,
Soft and fragrant, all come from the jeweled pools.
Lutes, zithers, flutes, and harps, adorned with the seven treasures,
Because the instruments are exquisite, the sounds are clear, all also come from trees.
The pÄrijÄta tree, the king of heavenly trees,
Is in that Joyous Garden, incomparable to anything else.
Upholding the precepts is like plowing the fields, heavenly trees emerge from within,
Heavenly kitchens with the taste of nectar, food and drink eliminate hunger and thirst.
Heavenly maidens are unobstructed, and there are also no difficulties of pregnancy,
Joyful and unrestrained pleasure, eating without the troubles of excrement and urine.
Upholding the precepts and always controlling the mind, one is born in a place of self-indulgence,
Without affairs and also without difficulties, one always obtains unrestrained pleasure.
The gods attain self-mastery, and worries and suffering no longer arise,
What is desired arrives upon thought, and the body's light illuminates the dark netherworld.
Such various pleasures, all come from giving and precepts,
If you wish to attain this reward, you should diligently strive for it!
Question:
Now that Å›Ä«la pÄramitÄ is being discussed, it should lead to becoming a Buddha. Why then do you praise heavenly blessings?
Answer:
The Buddha said that the three things that definitely lead to a non-empty reward are:
Giving leads to great wealth, upholding precepts leads to rebirth in a good place, and cultivating concentration leads to liberation.
If one practices Å›Ä«la alone, one can be reborn in a good place;
If one cultivates concentration, wisdom, and compassion together, one can attain the paths of the three vehicles.
Now, I am only praising the present-life merits of upholding precepts, fame, peace and joy, and the rewards of the next life, as praised in the verses.
It is like a child who is first given honey to coat a bitter medicine, and then is able to take it;
Now, I first praise the blessings of upholding precepts, and then people are able to uphold precepts.
After being able to uphold precepts, if one makes a great vow, one can reach the Buddha's path - this is called Å›Ä«la giving rise to Å›Ä«la pÄramitÄ.
Moreover, all people are attached to pleasure, and the pleasure of the world is supreme in the heavens.
If one hears about the various pleasures in the heavens, one can then practice the precepts;
Later, hearing that the heavens are impermanent, a mind of disgust arises, and one is able to seek liberation;
Hearing again about the Buddha's immeasurable merits and compassionate mind, one can attain the path to Buddhahood by relying on the perfection of morality.
For this reason, even though it is said that the retribution for morality is not a fault.
Question:
For lay people living at home, are there any other methods besides these five precepts?
Answer:
There is a one-day precept to be observed on the six monthly fasting days, with immeasurable merit;
If one observes this precept from the first to the fifteenth day of the twelfth month, the merit is very great.
Question:
How does one receive the one-day precept?
Answer:
The method of receiving the one-day precept is to kneel and join one's palms together, and say:
I, [name], for this one day and one night, take refuge in the Buddha, take refuge in the Dharma, take refuge in the Sangha!
Repeat this way two times, this way three times, taking refuge.
I, [name], have taken refuge in the Buddha, have taken refuge in the Dharma, have taken refuge in the Sangha.
Repeat this way two times, this way three times, having taken refuge.
I, [name], if with the body I have done what is unwholesome, if with speech I have done what is unwholesome, if with the mind I have done what is unwholesome, due to greed, hatred, and delusion,
if in this world or in a past world, I have such offenses, I now repent with sincere mind.

With the body pure, with speech pure, with mind pure, receiving and practicing the eight precepts, this is the poá¹£adha, meaning 'to dwell together' in the Qin language.ğŸ”½Just as the Buddhas, for as long as life lasts, do not kill living beings, I, [name], for this one day and one night, do not kill living beings in the same way;
just as the Buddhas, for as long as life lasts, do not steal, I, [name], for this one day and one night, do not steal in the same way;
Just as the Buddhas throughout their lives do not engage in sexual activity, I, [name], for one day and one night will not engage in sexual activity either;
Just as the Buddhas throughout their lives do not speak falsely, I, [name], for one day and one night will not speak falsely either;
Just as the Buddhas throughout their lives do not drink alcohol, I, [name], for one day and one night will not drink alcohol either;
Just as the Buddhas throughout their lives do not sit on high and luxurious beds, I, [name], for one day and one night will not sit on high and luxurious beds either;

Just as the Buddhas throughout their lives do not wear flowers, necklaces, perfume their bodies with fragrance, or wear fragrant incense-scented clothes, I, [name], for one day and one night will not wear flowers, necklaces, perfume my body with fragrance, or wear fragrant incense-scented clothes either;

Just as the Buddhas throughout their lives do not sing, dance, or make music themselves, nor do they go to watch or listen, I, [name], for one day and one night will not sing, dance, or make music myself, nor will I go to watch or listen either.
Having already received the eight precepts, just as the buddhas throughout their lives do not eat past noon, I, [name], for one day and one night do not eat past noon either.
I, [name], receive and practice the eight precepts, following the buddhas' teachings, and call it the poá¹£adha.
I wish to dedicate the merit of this poá¹£adha, and wish to be reborn without falling into the three evil destinies or the eight difficulties.
I also do not seek the bliss of a wheel-turning sage king, BrahmÄ, Åšakra, or the worlds;
I wish to exhaust all afflictions, attain omniscience, and accomplish buddhahood.
Question:
How does one receive the five precepts?
Answer:
The method of receiving the five precepts, kneeling and joining palms, says:
I, [name], take refuge in the Buddha, take refuge in the Dharma, take refuge in the Saá¹…gha!
Like this twice, like this three times.
I, [name], have taken refuge in the Buddha, have taken refuge in the Dharma, have taken refuge in the Saá¹…gha.
Like this twice, like this three times.
I am a lay disciple of ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha. Please bear witness to me. I, so-and-so, from this day until the end of my life, take refuge.
The precept master should say:
You lay disciple, listen!
This TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha, who knows people and sees people, has taught the five precepts to lay disciples like this. You should uphold them for the rest of your life!
What are the five?
For the rest of your life, do not kill living beings. This is the precept of a lay disciple. For the rest of your life, you should not intentionally kill;
if you are able to do this, you should say 'yes.'
For the rest of your life, do not steal. This is the precept of a lay disciple. For the rest of your life, you should not steal;
if you are able to do this, you should say 'yes.'
For the rest of your life, do not engage in sexual misconduct. This is the precept of a lay disciple. For the rest of your life, you should not engage in sexual misconduct;
if you are able to do this, you should say 'yes.'ğŸ”½For the rest of your life, do not lie. This is the precept of a lay disciple. For the rest of your life, you should not lie;
Not to lie for the rest of one's life is the precept of an upÄsaka. In this, for the rest of one's life one should not lie;
if one is able to do this, one should say 'yes.'
Not to drink alcohol for the rest of one's life is the precept of an upÄsaka. In this, for the rest of one's life one should not drink alcohol;
if one is able to do this, one should say 'yes.'
These are the five precepts of an upÄsaka, to be upheld for the rest of one's life.
One should make offerings to the Three Jewels:
the Buddha Jewel, the Dharma Jewel, and the Saá¹…gha Jewel of bhiká¹£us. Diligent in cultivating meritorious deeds, one should seek the Buddha's path!
Question:
Why observe the eight precepts and cultivate merit on the six days of purification?
Answer:
On these days, evil demons chase after people, wanting to take away people's lives, causing illness, misfortune, and making people inauspicious.
Therefore, in the beginning of the eon, sages taught people to observe the purification days, cultivate goodness, do meritorious deeds, and avoid misfortune.
At that time, the purification method did not involve observing the eight precepts, but simply fasting for one day as the purification.
Later, a Buddha appeared in the world and taught them, saying:

The question is:
Why did the father of the ghosts and spirits cut his flesh and blood on these six days and put it into the fire?
The answer is:
Among the gods, Mahesvara is the greatest and foremost. All the gods have their own days.
Mahesvara has four days in a month:
the eighth, twenty-third, fourteenth, and twenty-ninth.
Other gods have two days in a month:
The first and sixteenth days of the month, the second and seventeenth days of the month.
The fifteenth and thirtieth days belong to all the gods.
Mahesvara is the lord of all the gods, and since he obtained many days, the four days are counted as fast days;
The second day is the day of all the gods, and it is also counted as a fast day.

Question:
Are the five precepts and the one-day precepts which are superior?
Answer:
There are causes and conditions, and the two precepts are equal;
But the five precepts are observed for one's whole life, while the eight precepts are observed for one day.
Moreover, the five precepts are always observed, and the time is long but the precepts are few;
The one-day precepts are observed for a short time but the precepts are many.
Furthermore, even if one observes precepts all one's life without a great mind, it is not as good as a person with a great mind observing precepts for one day.
It is like a weak man being a general. Even if he leads troops all his life, his wisdom and bravery are insufficient and he ultimately has no merit or fame;
If he is like a hero who rises up, then chaos and disorder are immediately settled, and in one day's achievements, his merit covers the world.
These two kinds of precepts are called the Dharma of lay followers in the home.
There are generally four kinds of precepts observed by lay followers in the home:
There are lower, middle, upper, and highest.
Lower people observe precepts for the sake of worldly happiness;
Or out of fear, praise, and fame;
Or because of family rules, bending to others' intentions;
Or to avoid hard work and escape dangerous situations - such various reasons are lower people observing precepts.
Middle people observe precepts for the sake of wealth and nobility among humans, and to indulge their desires;

Or, expecting blessings and happiness in the next life, one disciplines oneself and strives, thinking that the suffering for a few days is small, but what one obtains is very muchâ€”thinking like this, one firmly upholds the precepts.
It is like a merchant who goes far and deep, and certainly obtains much profit.
The blessings of upholding the precepts cause one to receive blessings and happiness in the next life, it is also like this.
The superior person upholds the precepts for the sake of nirvana, knowing that all dharmas are impermanent, wishing to leave suffering and attain the bliss of the unconditioned.

Furthermore, for the person who upholds the precepts, their mind is without regret. Because the mind is without regret, one obtains joy and bliss. Because one obtains joy and bliss, one obtains one-pointedness of mind. Because one obtains one-pointedness of mind, one obtains true wisdom. Because one obtains true wisdom, one obtains a mind of disgust. Because one obtains a mind of disgust, one obtains detachment. Because one obtains detachment, one obtains liberation. Because one obtains liberation, one obtains nirvanaâ€”in this way, upholding the precepts is the root of all good dharmas.
Furthermore, keeping precepts is the initial gateway of the eightfold noble path. Entering the initial gateway of the path will surely lead to nirvana.
